1  II.  LEGAL STANDARD 
2  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) โtests the legal sufficiency of a claim.โ  
3  Navarro v. Block, 250 F.3d 729, 732 (9th Cir. 2001).  โDismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) is 
4  proper when the complaint either (1) lacks a cognizable legal theory or (2) fails to allege 
5  sufficient facts to support a cognizable legal theory.โ  Somers v. Apple, Inc., 729 F.3d 953, 
6  959 (9th Cir. 2013).  โRule 12(b)(6) is read in conjunction with Rule 8(a), which requires 
7  not only โfair notice of the nature of the claim, but also grounds on which the claim rests.โโ  
8  Zixiang Li v. Kerry, 710 F.3d 995, 998-99 (9th Cir. 2013) (quoting in part Bell Atl. Corp. 
9  v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 556 n.3 (2007)).  โTo survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint 
10  must contain sufficient factual matter, accepted as true, to โstate a claim to relief that is 
11  plausible on its face.โ โ Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (quoting Twombly, 550 
12  U.S. at 570 (2007)).   
13  In assessing the sufficiency of the pleadings, โcourts must consider the complaint in 
14  its entirety, as well as other sources courts ordinarily examine when ruling on Rule 12(b)(6) 
15  motions to dismiss, in particular, documents incorporated into the complaint by reference, 
16  and matters of which a court may take judicial notice.โ  Tellabs, Inc. v. Makor Issues & 
17  Rights, Ltd., 551 U.S. 308, 322 (2007).  The court is to โaccept all factual allegations in the 
18  complaint as true and construe the pleadings in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
19  party.โ  Outdoor Media Group, Inc. v. City of Beaumont, 506 F.3d 895, 899-900 (9th Cir. 
20  2007).  Where a complaint or claim is dismissed, leave to amend generally is granted, 
21  unless further amendment would be futile.  Cervantes v. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc.,  
22  656 F.3d 1034, 1041 (9th Cir. 2011). 
23  III.  DISCUSSION 
24  A.  42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 
25  Plaintiffsโ first claim for relief under ยง 1983 for denial of due process and 
26  interference with familial relations is directed against Officers Wade and Deguilo and CWS 
27  workers Diaz-Lara and Lefler Panela.  Section 1983 provides that individuals may sue 
28  government officials who violate their civil rights while acting โunder color of any statute, 
- 5 - 
 
   

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 6 of 22
 
1  ordinance, regulation, custom, or usage, of any State.โ  42 U.S.C. ยง 1983.  To maintain a 
2  claim pursuant to ยง 1983, a plaintiff must establish:  (1) the deprivation of any rights, 
3  privileges or immunities secured by the Constitution or federal law, (2) by a person acting 
4  under the color of state law.  See West v. Atkins, 487 U.S. 42, 48 (1988); Nurre v. 
5  Whitehead, 580 F.3d 1087, 1092 (9th Cir. 2009).  In addition, defendantโs actions must 
6  both actually and proximately cause the deprivation of a federally protected right.  Lemire 
7  v. Caifornia Depโt of Corrections & Rehabilitation, 726 F.3d 1062, 1074 (9th Cir. 2013).  
8  Section 1983 is not itself a source of substantive rights, but a jurisdictional vehicle for 
9  vindicating federal rights elsewhere conferred.  See Thornton v. City of St. Helens, 425 
10  F.3d 1158, 1164 (9th Cir. 2008) (citations omitted).  
11  1.  Due Process 
12  โThe Fourteenth Amendment prohibits states from โdepriv[ing] any person of life, 
13  liberty, or property, without due process of law.โโ  Newman v. Sathyavaglswaran, 287 F.3d 
14  786, 789 (9th Cir. 2002) (quoting U.S. Const. amend. XIV, ยง 1).  The Due Process Clause 
15  encompasses two types of protections:  procedural fairness (procedural due process) and 
16  substantive rights (substantive due process).  Zinermon v. Burch, 494 U.S. 113, 125-28 
17  (1990).  A procedural due process claim challenges the procedures used in effecting a 
18  deprivation, whereas a substantive due process claim challenges the governmental action 
19  itself.  See Brittain v. Hansen, 451 F.3d 982, 991 (9th Cir. 2006).   
20  Here, the gist of Plaintiffsโ due process claim is that Defendants violated their 
21  mandatory duties to investigate and report child abuse, which, in turn, led to Kayleighโs 
22  murder.  FAC ยถยถ 64-66.  Although the pleadings do not specify whether the due process 
23  claim is based on substantive or procedural due process, Plaintiffs state in their opposition 
24  that they are proceeding on both legal theories. 
25  a)  Substantive Due Process 
26  Generally, โa Stateโs failure to protect an individual against private violence simply 
27  does not constitute a violation of the Due Process Clause.โ  DeShaney v. Winnebago Cnty. 
28  Depโt of Soc. Servs., 489 U.S. 189, 196 (1989) (holding that a social services agency and 
- 6 - 
 
   

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 7 of 22
 
1  social workers did not violate a child victimโs substantive due process rights by failing to 
2  protect him from his abusive father, notwithstanding significant evidence establishing that 
3  the child was subjected to beatings).  โThere are two exceptions to this rule:  (1) when a 
4  โspecial relationshipโ exists between the plaintiff and the state (the special-relationship 
5  exception) . . . ; and (2) when the state affirmatively places the plaintiff in danger by acting 
6  with โdeliberate  indifferenceโ to a โknown or obvious dangerโ (the state-created danger 
7  exception) . . . .โ  Patel v. Kent School Dist., 648 F.3d 965, 971-72 (9th Cir. 2011) 
8  (citations omitted).  Plaintiffs rely on the state-created danger exception, sometimes simply 
9  referred to as the โdanger creationโ exception.  Kennedy v. City of Ridgefield, 439 F.3d 
10  1055, 1062 (9th Cir. 2006) (citing DeShaney, 489 U.S. at 197). 
11  โ[A] police officerโs conduct that affirmatively places a plaintiff in a position of 
12  danger deprives him or her of a substantive due process right.โ  Johnson v. City of Seattle, 
13  474 F.3d 634, 639 (9th Cir. 2007) (citing Wood v. Ostrander, 879 F.2d 583, 589-90 (9th 
14  Cir. 1989)).  โTo determine whether an official affirmatively placed an individual in 
15  danger, we ask: (1) whether any affirmative actions of the official placed the individual in 
16  danger he otherwise would not have faced; (2) whether the danger was known or obvious; 
17  and (3) whether the officer acted with deliberate indifference to that danger.โ  Henry A. v. 
18  Willden, 678 F.3d 991, 1002 (9th Cir. 2012).     
19  For example, in Wood, a trooper stopped a car in which the plaintiff was a 
20  passenger, arrested the driver for drunk driving, and left the plaintiff in a high crime area at 
21  2:30 a.m.  The plaintiff later accepted a ride from a stranger and was raped.  The Ninth 
22  Circuit reversed a summary judgment ruling in favor of the trooper, finding that there was 
23  โa factual dispute regarding whether [the trooper] deprived her of a liberty interest 
24  protected by the Constitution by affirmatively placing her in danger and then abandoning 
25  her.โ  Id. at 596.  Similarly, in Maxwell v. County of San Diego, 708 F.3d 1075 (9th Cir. 
26  2013), the court found that the police officers affirmatively increased the danger to an 
27  individual who had been shot and later died by preventing her ambulance from leaving the 
28  scene.  Id. at 1082.  The court explained that the delay left the victim โworse off than if the 
- 7 - 
 
   

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 8 of 22
 
1  ambulance had been allowed to bring her to an air ambulance that had advanced medical 
2  capabilities and was ready to fly her to a trauma center.โ  Id. 
3  Plaintiffs argue that the Ninth Circuitโs decision in Kennedy, in particular, supports 
4  the application of the danger creation exception.  In Kennedy, the plaintiff, the mother of a 
5  nine year-old girl, reported to the police that a thirteen year-old neighbor had molested her 
6  daughter.  In response to the motherโs concern regarding the neighborโs history of violence, 
7  the officer told her that she would be given notice prior to any police contact with the 
8  neighborโs family regarding her allegations.  Kennedy, 439 F.2d at 1058.  Despite those 
9  assurances, the police officer, without first notifying the mother, informed the neighbor and 
10  his mother of the plaintiffโs claim of molestation.  When the plaintiff learned of this, she 
11  asked the officer why he had contacted the neighbor without first notifying her, and 
12  expressed serious concerns for her safety.  In response, the officer โassured [the plaintiff] 
13  that the police would patrol the area around both her house and the [neighborโs] house that 
14  night to keep an eye on [him].โ  Id.  Due to the late hour and the officerโs promise to patrol 
15  the neighborhood, the plaintiff and her husband decided to stay at their house.  Id.  The 
16  following morning, the neighbor broke into the plaintiffโs home and shot her and her 
17  husband, killing him, as they slept.  Id.  In upholding the denial of qualified immunity for 
18  the officer, the Ninth Circuit held that the officer โaffirmatively created a danger to [the 
19  plaintiff] she otherwise would not have faced, i.e., that [the neighbor] would be notified of 
20  the allegations before the [parents] had the opportunity to protect themselves from his 
21  violent response to the news.โ  Id. 
22  Plaintiffs contend that Defendantsโ failure to investigate and report on the suspected 
23  abuse of Kayleigh, in tandem with Officer Wadeโs โfalseโ assurance that โeverything 
24  appeared normalโ at Kayleighโs home and that he would โkeep an eye on the apartment,  
25  affirmatively increased the risk of harm to Kayleigh.  Pls.โ Oppโn at City Defs.โ Mot. to 
26  Dismiss at 9-10.  The Court disagrees.  In Kennedy, the affirmative danger created by the 
27  officer was his informing the neighbor of the plaintiffโs accusations before she and her 
28  husband could protect themselves against the neighborโs violent responseโcoupled with 
- 8 - 
 
   

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 9 of 22
 
1  his assurance to monitor the defendant.  439 F.3d at 1058.  Here, the risk to Kayleigh was 
2  the fact that she lived with adults who were abusive.  While Defendants were allegedly 
3  derelict in their failure to extricate Kayleigh from that situation, no facts are alleged that 
4  suggest that they placed her in danger or affirmatively increased the risk of harm to her 
5  through their inaction.  Despite Plaintiffsโ intimations to the contrary, Kennedy does not 
6  support the proposition that false assurances by a law enforcement officer, standing alone, 
7  can affirmatively create a danger.  439 F.3d at 1063.  To the contrary, the court simply 
8  explained that such misrepresentations can constitute โan additional and aggravating factor, 
9  making [the plaintiff] more vulnerable to the danger he had already created.โ  Id. 
10  Construing the facts in a light most favorable to Plaintiffs, the pleadings, at most, 
11  demonstrate that Defendants knew or had reason to know that Kayleigh was at serious risk 
12  of harm.  Absent from the pleadings are any facts demonstrating that Defendants 
13  affirmatively placed Kayleigh in a position that increased such risk.  See DeShaney, 489 
14  U.S. at 201 (โWhile the State may have been aware of the dangers that Joshua faced in the 
15  free world, it played no part in their creation, nor did it do anything to render him any more 
16  vulnerable to them.โ).  As such, the Court finds that Plaintiff has failed to state a claim 
17  based on the denial of the right to substantive due process.  The foregoing notwithstanding, 
18  it is possible that Plaintiffs will be able to rectify these deficiencies through the presentation 
19  of additional facts.  Accordingly, Plaintiffs are granted leave to amend their substantive due 
20  process claim. 
21  b)  Procedural Due Process 
22  The procedural due process component of the Fourteenth Amendment protects 
23  individuals against the deprivation of liberty or property by the government without due 
24  process.  Portman v. Cnty. of Santa Clara, 995 F.2d 898, 904 (9th Cir. 1993).  โState law 
25  can create a right that the Due Process Clause will protect only if the state law contains 
26  โ(1) substantive predicates governing official decisionmaking, and (2) explicitly mandatory 
27  language specifying the outcome that must be reached if the substantive predicates have 
28 
- 9 - 
 
   

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 10 of 22
 
1  been met.โโ  James v. Rowlands, 606 F.3d 646, 656 (9th Cir. 2010) (quoting Bonin v. 
2  Calderon, 59 F.3d 815, 842 (9th Cir. 1995)). 
3  According to the FAC, Plaintiffsโ protected property interest arises principally from 
4  the mandatory child abuse reporting requirements set forth in the California Child Abuse 
5  and Neglect Reporting Act (โCANRAโ), Cal. Pen. Code ยงยง 11164-11174.4.  FAC ยถ 64.  
6  Among other things, CANRA provides that specified โmandated reporters,โ which include 
7  social workers and police officers, โshall make a report to an agency specified in Section 
8  11165.9 whenever the mandated reporter, in his or her professional capacity or within the 
9  scope of his or her employment, has knowledge of or observes a child whom the mandated 
10  reporter knows or reasonably suspects has been the victim of child abuse or neglect.โ  Cal. 
11  Pen. Code ยง 11166(a) (emphasis added); see also id. ยง 11165.7(a) (list of โmandated 
12  reportersโ).  California courts have construed this provision as imposing โtwo mandatory 
13  dutiesโ on a mandated reporter who receives an account of child abuse:  (1) the duty to 
14  investigate; and (2) the duty to file a report of child abuse when an objectively reasonable 
15  person in the same situation would suspect abuse.  Alejo v. City of Alhambra, 75 
16  Cal.App.4th 1180, 1186 (1999).5  A violation of section 11166โs duties constitutes a 
17  misdemeanor offense.  Cal. Pen. Code ยง 11166(c). 
18  The County Defendants contend that CANRA only creates a discretionary as 
19  opposed to a mandatory duty and therefore fails to provide any โsubstantive predicates to 
20  decision-making.โ  County Defs.โ Mot. to Dismiss at 6.  They posit that since the reporting 
21  obligation is triggered only upon a โreasonable suspicionโ of child abuse, a mandated 
22  reporter inherently must use discretion in determining whether to make a report of 
23  suspected child abuse in the first instance.  Id.  These contentions are uncompelling.  The 
24  plain language of the statute clearly states that a โmandated reporter shall make a reportโ to 
25  CPS, police, or other law enforcement agency upon a reasonable suspicion of child abuse or 
26 
                                                 
27  5 The Alejo court noted that while the duty to investigate is not express, it is clearly 
envisioned by the statute so the officer can determine whether there is a reasonable 
28  suspicion of child abuse. 75 Cal.App.4th at 1186.

Case 4:15-cv-02394-SBA   Document 45   Filed 12/11/15   Page 11 of 22
 
1  neglect.  Cal. Pen. Code ยง 11166(a) (emphasis added).  As noted, California courts have 
2  construed this obligation as a โmandatoryโ one.  Alejo, 75 Cal.App.4th at 1185-86; see also 
3  Tarrant Bell Property, LLC v. Superior Court, 51 Cal.4th 538, 542 (2011) (noting that the 
4  Legislatureโs use of the word โshallโ denotes a mandatory act).  Defendantsโ assertion that 
5  no mandatory duty is imposed under CANRA also is undermined by the fact that the statute 
6  explicitly requires that a mandated reporter apply an objective standard in determining 
7  whether there is reasonable suspicion a child has been abused or neglected.  Cal. Pen. Code 
8  ยง 11166(a)(1); see Olim v. Wakinekona, 461 U.S. 238, 249 (1983) (โIf the decisionmaker is 
9  not โrequired to base its decisions on objective and defined criteria,โ but instead โcan deny 
10  the requested relief for any constitutionally permissible reason or for no reason at all,โ the 
11  State has not created a constitutionally protected liberty interest.โ) (citations omitted). 
12  Having concluded above that CANRA provides โsubstantive predicatesโ to guide the 
13  decisionmaker, the question becomes whether it also contains โโexplicitly mandatory 
14  language,โ i.e., specific directives to the decisionmaker that if the regulationsโ substantive 
15  predicates are present, a particular outcome must follow . . . .โ  Kentucky Dept. of 
16  Corrections v. Thompson, 490 U.S. 454, 463 (1989).  In Thompson, the Supreme Court 
17  considered whether prison regulations governing visitation could give rise to a protected 
18  liberty interest.  The Court found that while the regulations โdo provide certain โsubstantive 
19  predicatesโ to guide the decisionmaker,โ they โlack the requisite relevant mandatory 
20  languageโ because โ[t]hey stop short of requiring that a particular result is to be reached 
21  upon a finding that the substantive predicates are met.โ  Id. at 463-64.  In particular, the 
22  procedures at issue granted administrative staff discretion whether to allow or disallow 
23  visits, such that the โoverall effect of the regulations is not such that an inmate can 
24  reasonably form an objective expectation that a visit would necessarily be allowed absent

11  2.  Familial Association 
12  The Fourteenth Amendment protects the liberty interest in familial companionship 
13  and association against unwarranted governmental interference.  See Wilkinson v. 
14  Torres, 610 F.3d 546, 554 (9th Cir. 2010); Crowe v. Cnty. of San Diego, 608 F.3d 406, 441 
15  & n. 23 (9th Cir. 2010).  The liberty interest in familial companionship encompasses the 
16  familial relationship between parents and children.  Curnow By and Through Curnow v. 
17  Ridgecrest Police, 952 F.2d 321, 325 (9th Cir. 1991).  โMoreover, the First Amendment 
18  protects those relationships, including family relationships, that presuppose deep 
19  attachments and commitments to the necessarily few other individuals with whom one 
20  shares not only a special community of thoughts, experiences, and beliefs but also 
21  distinctively personal aspects of oneโs life.โ  Lee v. City of Los Angeles, 250 F.3d 668, 685 
22  (9th Cir. 2001). 
23  Defendants contend that Plaintiffsโ familial association claim must be dismissed 
24  because the pleadings fail to demonstrate an underlying constitutional violation.  Though it 
25  has not addressed this issue directly, the Ninth Circuit has intimated that an underlying due 
26  process violation is a prerequisite to a claim for denial of familial association claim based 
27  on the Fourteenth Amendment.  See, e.g., Lee, 250 F.3d at 685 (โ[T]he stateโs interference 
28  with [the right of familial association] without due process of law is remediable under 42

3  A Monell claim may take one of three forms:  (1) โwhen implementation of its 
4  official policies or established customs inflicts the constitutional injuryโ; (2) when 
5  omissions or failures to act amount to a local government policy of โdeliberate 
6  indifferenceโ to constitutional rights7; or (3) when a local government official with final 
7  policy-making authority ratifies a subordinateโs unconstitutional conduct.  Clouthier v. 
8  Cnty. of Contra Costa, 591 F.3d 1232, 1249-50 (9th Cir. 2010).  To state a claim, the 
9  pleadings need only โcontain sufficient allegations of underlying facts to give fair notice 
10  and to enable the opposing party to defend itself effectively.โ  AE ex rel. Hernandez v. 
11  Cnty. of Tulare, 666 F.3d 631, 637 (9th Cir. 2012) (addressing the pleading requirements 
12  applicable to a Monell claim).  In addition, the facts alleged must โplausibly suggest an 
13  entitlement to relief, such that it is not unfair to require the opposing party to be subjected 
14  to the expense of discovery and continued litigation.โ  Id.  Here, Plaintiffs seek to state a 
15  claim under each of three aforementioned theories of liability; to wit, the existence of a 
16  policy or custom, ratification and failure to train.

3  4.  Qualified Immunity 
4  Defendants contend, in the alternative, that they are entitled to qualified immunity 
5  with respect to Plaintiffsโ federal claims.  โThe doctrine of qualified immunity protects 
6  government officials โfrom liability for civil damages insofar as their conduct does not 
7  violate clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person 
8  would have known.โโ  Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223, 231 (2009) (quoting Harlow v. 
9  Fitzgerald, 457 U.S. 800, 818 (1982)).  When presented with a qualified immunity defense, 
10  the court considers: (1) whether the facts alleged, taken in the light most favorable to the 
11  plaintiff, demonstrate that the defendantโs conduct violated a statutory or constitutional 
12  right; and (2) whether the right at issue was โclearly established.โ  Saucier v. Katz, 533 
13  U.S. 194, 201 (2001). 
14  In view of the dismissal of Plaintiffsโ due process claims with leave to amend, it is 
15  unnecessary at this juncture to determine whether those claims are precluded by the 
16  doctrine of qualified immunity.  As for Plaintiffsโ remaining First Amendment-based 
17  familial association claim, Defendants fail to discuss that claim specifically.  Accordingly, 
18  the Defendantsโ motion to dismiss based on qualified immunity is denied at this time.

18  be held in abeyance pending the settlement conference.  In the event the parties are unable 
19  to reach a settlement, Defendants shall file their responsive pleading or Rule 12(b) motion 
20  within fourteen (14) days of the conclusion of the settlement conference. 
21  IT IS SO ORDERED.
